Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[♪ INTRO ♪] Parents have a bunch of catchphrases. Things like, “Don’t eat with your mouth
open” or “Don’t run with scissors." Another one you might recognize is “don’t sit too close to the TV; it’ll hurt your eyes." But it turns out that the science behind that one isn’t actually true—at least, not anymore. Your eyes might start to feel tired, but the
TV won’t actually hurt them. That idea came from some faulty televisions back in the late 1960s. About 50 years ago, General Electric accidentally released a line of color televisions that emitted X-rays from 10 to 100,000 times more than was considered safe. Talk about a manufacturing flaw. Like most other old, boxy TVs, the GE ones used cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, to generate a picture. Inside the glass vacuum tubes, electrons were fired at a screen covered in red, green, and blue phosphors, a type of material that glows when hit by something like electrons. And when fast-moving electrons strike something in a vacuum, it generates X-rays. To protect people from this radiation, engineers mixed lead into the glass ray tubes— but this batch of GE televisions was produced with faulty tubes. Two pieces were misaligned, which meant that the X-rays were deflected out of the bottom of the TV set and toward the ground right under
the television, where some kid was probably singing along to The Flintstones theme song. A recall notice estimated that sitting under the TV for a total of 40 hours would expose someone to so much radiation that their skin would turn red and painful. Which is... not great. But the good news is it doesn’t seem like
anyone was hurt. Thankfully, modern LCD TVs don’t emit harmful radiation at all, so you can sit as close as you want. But if you do spend too much time binging Netflix, you might still develop a headache. If you stare at the TV—or basically anything, including a book or your smartphone—for too long, you can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain. After a while, whatever you’re staring at
will start to get wobbly and fuzzy, and you might get a headache or feel tired. Fortunately there’s an easy fix: Go do something else, or at least just look away for a few seconds. Now, kids can focus on things close up much better than adults can without developing eye-strain, which is why they tend to get in the habit of sitting super close to screens—like televisions. And, in the 1960s, that might have been a
problem. But today, kids won’t get radiation burns
by doing it, no matter what their parents say. So the next time you’re in the mood for
a vintage movie marathon, you can sit wherever you’d like. But when Netflix asks you if you’re still
watching, it might be time to give your eyes a break. Thanks for asking, and thanks to all of our patrons on Patreon who keep the answers coming. If you’d like to submit a question to be
answered, you can go to patreon.com/scishow. [♪ OUTRO ♪]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Modern LCD TVs emit harmful radiation. True or false?
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason behind the warning "don't sit too close to the TV; it'll hurt your eyes"? Options: A. The TV emitted X-rays due to a manufacturing flaw., B. The TV screen was too bright and could cause eye-strain., C. The TV was too heavy and could fall on someone., D. The TV had a sharp edge that could cut someone. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What type of material was used in old TVs to generate a picture? Options: A. Liquid crystals, B. Cathode ray tubes (CRTs), C. Plasma screens, D. LED lights Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you stare at a screen for too long, what can happen to your eyes? Options: A. You can develop radiation burns., B. You can tire out the muscles in and around your eyes and develop eye-strain., C. You can improve your eyesight., D. You can see more colors. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did engineers mix lead into the glass ray tubes of old TVs? Options: A. To make the TVs heavier., B. To protect people from radiation., C. To make the TVs more colorful., D. To make the TVs more energy-efficient. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the estimated time it would take for someone to be exposed to harmful radiation from the faulty GE TVs? Options: A. 1 hour, B. 10 hours, C. 40 hours, D. 100 hours Correct Option: C
Question 6: A child is watching TV on a modern LCD screen. What is the most likely outcome if they sit too close to the screen for an extended period? Options: A. They will develop radiation burns., B. They will develop eye-strain and possibly a headache., C. They will improve their eyesight., D. They will see more colors. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why do kids tend to sit closer to screens than adults? Options: A. Because they have better eyesight., B. Because they are more curious., C. Because they can focus on things close up better without developing eye-strain., D. Because they are more reckless. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a simple solution to prevent eye-strain when watching TV or staring at a screen? Options: A. Wearing glasses., B. Sitting farther away from the screen., C. Looking away from the screen for a few seconds., D. Turning off the screen. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main difference between old CRT TVs and modern LCD TVs in terms of radiation emission? Options: A. Old CRT TVs emitted less radiation than modern LCD TVs., B. Old CRT TVs emitted more radiation than modern LCD TVs., C. Old CRT TVs emitted radiation, while modern LCD TVs do not., D. Old CRT TVs did not emit radiation, while modern LCD TVs do. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the warning "don't sit too close to the TV; it'll hurt your eyes"? Options: A. The warning is still relevant today., B. The warning was never relevant., C. The warning was relevant in the past due to a manufacturing flaw, but it is no longer relevant today., D. The warning is only relevant for adults. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: What is the main difference between old CRT TVs and modern LCD TVs in terms of radiation emission? Options: A. Old CRT TVs emitted less radiation than modern LCD TVs., B. Old CRT TVs emitted more radiation than modern LCD TVs., C. Old CRT TVs emitted radiation, while modern LCD TVs do not., D. Old CRT TVs did not emit radiation, while modern LCD TVs do. Correct Option: C

This question directly addresses the same topic as the ground truth MCQ, which is whether modern LCD TVs emit harmful radiation. The correct option, C, states that old CRT TVs emitted radiation, while modern LCD TVs do not, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's correct answer, B. False.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. Wild banana plants are native to_____?
Options: A. South America, B. Southeast Asia, C. South Asia, D. both B and C
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the number one selling item at Wal-mart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Bananas, D. Fifty Shades of Grey Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas not have visible seeds? Options: A. They were genetically engineered to be seedless, B. The seeds have stopped existing over time, C. The seeds are too small to be seen, D. The seeds are not fertile Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. Lack of demand, B. Infection by a fungicide-resistant pathogen, C. Genetic modification, D. Environmental factors Correct Option: B
Question 4: How are Cavendish bananas typically reproduced, since they are seedless? Options: A. Through genetic engineering, B. By transplanting part of the plant stem, C. By cross-pollination with other varieties, D. By using fertilizers Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential consequence of having a global monoculture of genetically identical bananas? Options: A. Increased resistance to diseases, B. Improved flavor and texture, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. Increased vulnerability to pathogens Correct Option: D
Question 6: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety from the Panama disease? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why do banana-flavored products often not taste like the bananas we eat today? Options: A. Because they are made with artificial flavorings, B. Because they are based on the Gros Michel variety, C. Because they are made with a different type of fruit, D. Because they are not ripe yet Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be inferred about the impact of human activity on the evolution of bananas? Options: A. Humans have had no impact on the evolution of bananas, B. Humans have contributed to the decline of certain banana varieties, C. Humans have improved the genetic diversity of bananas, D. Humans have created new species of bananas Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the disease that has been identified as a threat to the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Panama disease, B. Banana blight, C. Fungal infection, D. Genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas are in no danger of becoming extinct, B. The Cavendish variety is safe from disease, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect bananas from disease and ensure their continued availability, D. Bananas will soon become a rare and expensive fruit Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not a direct match, but Question 8 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since the options of Question 8 do not match the ground truth MCQ, I will provide an alternative solution.

A more suitable approach would be to create a new generated MCQ that directly matches the ground truth MCQ. Since this is not an option, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is closest in terms of question intent and content, which is:

 Question 8 (Note: This is not a direct match)

Options: A. South America, B. Southeast Asia, C. South Asia, D. both B and C

Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 4. Since the 1960's, all the bananas that people have eaten have been
Options: A. sterile mutants, B. the Cavendish variety, C. genetically identical to every other banana, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the number one selling item at Wal-mart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Bananas, D. Fifty Shades of Grey Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas not have visible seeds? Options: A. They were genetically engineered to be seedless, B. The seeds have stopped existing over time, C. The seeds are too small to be seen, D. The seeds are not fertile Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. Lack of demand, B. Infection by a fungicide-resistant pathogen, C. Genetic modification, D. Environmental factors Correct Option: B
Question 4: How are Cavendish bananas typically reproduced, since they are seedless? Options: A. Through genetic engineering, B. By transplanting part of the plant stem, C. By cross-pollination with other varieties, D. By using fertilizers Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential consequence of having a global monoculture of genetically identical bananas? Options: A. Increased resistance to diseases, B. Improved flavor and texture, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. Increased vulnerability to pathogens Correct Option: D
Question 6: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety from the Panama disease? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why do banana-flavored products often not taste like the bananas we eat today? Options: A. Because they are made with artificial flavorings, B. Because they are based on the Gros Michel variety, C. Because they are made with a different type of fruit, D. Because they are not ripe yet Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be inferred about the impact of human activity on the evolution of bananas? Options: A. Humans have had no impact on the evolution of bananas, B. Humans have contributed to the decline of certain banana varieties, C. Humans have improved the genetic diversity of bananas, D. Humans have created new species of bananas Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the disease that has been identified as a threat to the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Panama disease, B. Banana blight, C. Fungal infection, D. Genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas are in no danger of becoming extinct, B. The Cavendish variety is safe from disease, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect bananas from disease and ensure their continued availability, D. Bananas will soon become a rare and expensive fruit Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 5. Why was the Gros Michel variety of banana so easily killed off by Panama disease?
Options: A. Panama disease was fungicide resistant, B. all Gros Michel bananas were genetically similar, C. the seeds of the Gros Michel bananas were infertile, D. both a and b
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the number one selling item at Wal-mart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Bananas, D. Fifty Shades of Grey Correct Option: C

Question 3: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. Lack of demand, B. Infection by a fungicide-resistant pathogen, C. Genetic modification, D. Environmental factors Correct Option: B
Question 4: How are Cavendish bananas typically reproduced, since they are seedless? Options: A. Through genetic engineering, B. By transplanting part of the plant stem, C. By cross-pollination with other varieties, D. By using fertilizers Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential consequence of having a global monoculture of genetically identical bananas? Options: A. Increased resistance to diseases, B. Improved flavor and texture, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. Increased vulnerability to pathogens Correct Option: D
Question 6: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety from the Panama disease? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why do banana-flavored products often not taste like the bananas we eat today? Options: A. Because they are made with artificial flavorings, B. Because they are based on the Gros Michel variety, C. Because they are made with a different type of fruit, D. Because they are not ripe yet Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be inferred about the impact of human activity on the evolution of bananas? Options: A. Humans have had no impact on the evolution of bananas, B. Humans have contributed to the decline of certain banana varieties, C. Humans have improved the genetic diversity of bananas, D. Humans have created new species of bananas Correct Option: B

Scientists and growers are working to protect bananas from disease and ensure their continued availability, D. Bananas will soon become a rare and expensive fruit Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if
you have any questions, comments or suggestions for us, you can find us on
Facebook, Twitter or in the comments below, and if you want to
continue getting smarter this year at SciShow, you can go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe. [banana eating noises] [music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 2. Fruits are fleshy bodies containing____
Options: A. no seeds, B. seeds
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the number one selling item at Wal-mart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Bananas, D. Fifty Shades of Grey Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas not have visible seeds? Options: A. They were genetically engineered to be seedless, B. The seeds have stopped existing over time, C. The seeds are too small to be seen, D. The seeds are not fertile Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. Lack of demand, B. Infection by a fungicide-resistant pathogen, C. Genetic modification, D. Environmental factors Correct Option: B
Question 4: How are Cavendish bananas typically reproduced, since they are seedless? Options: A. Through genetic engineering, B. By transplanting part of the plant stem, C. By cross-pollination with other varieties, D. By using fertilizers Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential consequence of having a global monoculture of genetically identical bananas? Options: A. Increased resistance to diseases, B. Improved flavor and texture, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. Increased vulnerability to pathogens Correct Option: D
Question 6: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety from the Panama disease? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why do banana-flavored products often not taste like the bananas we eat today? Options: A. Because they are made with artificial flavorings, B. Because they are based on the Gros Michel variety, C. Because they are made with a different type of fruit, D. Because they are not ripe yet Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be inferred about the impact of human activity on the evolution of bananas? Options: A. Humans have had no impact on the evolution of bananas, B. Humans have contributed to the decline of certain banana varieties, C. Humans have improved the genetic diversity of bananas, D. Humans have created new species of bananas Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the disease that has been identified as a threat to the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Panama disease, B. Banana blight, C. Fungal infection, D. Genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas are in no danger of becoming extinct, B. The Cavendish variety is safe from disease, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect bananas from disease and ensure their continued availability, D. Bananas will soon become a rare and expensive fruit Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas not have visible seeds? 

Although the question is not an exact match, the correct option (B) "The seeds have stopped existing over time" implies that fruits, in this case, bananas, are fleshy bodies that would normally contain seeds. This aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the characteristic of fruits as fleshy bodies containing seeds.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 10
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Here at SciShow HQ we have a little food area for the employees - Sometimes there are donuts. Sometimes there are nuts. Sometimes dried mango. But the one thing that never sticks around and is gone as soon as we can buy it is the wonderful, beautiful, noble banana. Unfortunately for us, they may not be around forever. [Intro Music] First, the good: bananas are healthy,
packed with nutrition and energy, they fit in your hand and give nice little
cues when they're perfectly ripe, and are easy to peel and eat; shocking statistic,
the banana is Wal-mart's number one selling item.
Not the potato chip, not Coca-Cola, not Fifty Shades of Grey, bananas. They
appear to be so perfect for human consumption that Kirk Cameron attempted
to use them to prove the existence of God. Of course this banana was not created by
God, or really even nature. Bananas, at least the ones that you see at the store, were created by people. Don't get me
wrong, there are wild banana plants - lots of them - they're native to South and
Southeast Asia, and there are dozens of species and
thousands of varieties. They're just not the ones we eat. Some
those species, as you might suspect, have seeds, 'cause that's what fruits
are, they're fleshy bodies containing seeds. So you might wonder, why have you never
eaten a banana seed? Well, you have... kinda. In cultivated bananas the
seeds have pretty much stopped existing. If you look closely you can see tiny black specks. Those are all that's
left, and they're not fertile seeds. If you
plant them, nothing grows. Today's bananas are sterile mutants. I'm
not trying to be mean, that's just the truth. Unless you were alive in the 1960's (hats off to all those older SciShow viewers out there) every banana you
have ever eaten was pretty much genetically identical. This is a Cavendish, the virtually seedless
variety that we all eat today, but it wasn't always our banana of choice. Until the
1960s, everyone was eating the same banana, it
was just a different banana - the Gros Michel, a bigger, sweeter fruit
with thicker skin. You might notice that banana flavored things don't really
taste like bananas. Well they do - they taste like the Gros Michel. The
genetic monotony of the Gros Michel crop was its undoing. A fungicide
resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began
infecting Gros Michel crop. By the time growers understood how
vulnerable their crops were, the Gros Michel variety was all but extinct. The entire banana industry had to be
retooled for the Cavendish. Since they're seedless, the only way to reproduce them
is to transplant part of the plant stem, and for the last 50 years we've been
good with the Cavendish, 'cause it's more resistant to the Panama
disease. However somewhat terrifyingly a strain of Panama disease that affects
the Cavendish strain that we all eat has been identified. A global monoculture of genetically
identical individuals is a beautiful sight to a pathogen. The fungus only has to figure out how to
infect and destroy a single individual, and suddenly there is no diversity to
stop it, or even slow it down. That's led to a lot
of scientists worrying about or even predicting the outright demise of the
Cavendish. This wonderful most popular of fruits might
completely cease existence. The good news is we now have a much better
understanding of genetics, epidemics, fungi, and pathology.
Scientists and growers have already taken steps to protect the Cavendish. Some growers are creating genetically
different bananas that might replace the Cavendish crop if it fails, while
scientists are attempting to genetically engineer Cavendish plants with immunity
to Panama disease. Plus we learned a lot from the Gros
Michel debacle. Infected fields are quickly being destroyed and new crops are
grown from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock. So thanks to the people who work
tirelessly to grow and harvest bananas and bring them to us so that we can offer them inexpensively
to our employees, and thanks to the growers and scientists working
tirelessly to make sure that they don't go the way of the Gros Michel. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow, if

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 5. Why was the Gros Michel variety of banana so easily killed off by Panama disease?
Options: A. Panama disease was fungicide resistant, B. all Gros Michel bananas were genetically similar, C. the seeds of the Gros Michel bananas were infertile, D. both a and b
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the number one selling item at Wal-mart, according to the transcript? Options: A. Potato chips, B. Coca-Cola, C. Bananas, D. Fifty Shades of Grey Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why do cultivated bananas not have visible seeds? Options: A. They were genetically engineered to be seedless, B. The seeds have stopped existing over time, C. The seeds are too small to be seen, D. The seeds are not fertile Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety? Options: A. Lack of demand, B. Infection by a fungicide-resistant pathogen, C. Genetic modification, D. Environmental factors Correct Option: B
Question 4: How are Cavendish bananas typically reproduced, since they are seedless? Options: A. Through genetic engineering, B. By transplanting part of the plant stem, C. By cross-pollination with other varieties, D. By using fertilizers Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential consequence of having a global monoculture of genetically identical bananas? Options: A. Increased resistance to diseases, B. Improved flavor and texture, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. Increased vulnerability to pathogens Correct Option: D
Question 6: What are scientists and growers doing to protect the Cavendish banana variety from the Panama disease? Options: A. Creating genetically different bananas, B. Genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity, C. Destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free stock, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why do banana-flavored products often not taste like the bananas we eat today? Options: A. Because they are made with artificial flavorings, B. Because they are based on the Gros Michel variety, C. Because they are made with a different type of fruit, D. Because they are not ripe yet Correct Option: B
Question 8: What can be inferred about the impact of human activity on the evolution of bananas? Options: A. Humans have had no impact on the evolution of bananas, B. Humans have contributed to the decline of certain banana varieties, C. Humans have improved the genetic diversity of bananas, D. Humans have created new species of bananas Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the disease that has been identified as a threat to the Cavendish banana variety? Options: A. Panama disease, B. Banana blight, C. Fungal infection, D. Genetic disorder Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the future of bananas? Options: A. Bananas are in no danger of becoming extinct, B. The Cavendish variety is safe from disease, C. Scientists and growers are working to protect bananas from disease and ensure their continued availability, D. Bananas will soon become a rare and expensive fruit Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3 and Question 8, however Question 3 and Question 8 options do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ options. 

However, Question 8 talks about the human impact on bananas and Question 3 talks about the decline of Gros Michel banana variety.

But if we want to match the intent of the ground truth MCQ, then the best match is Question 3 and Question 8 combined.

However, if we want to choose one, then the best match is Question 3.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
there are 196 countries in the world
today and virtually none of them have purple on their national flag.
Throughout history, purple was never used to represent a kingdom civilization or
Empire. So what's wrong with purple? It's such a popular color today.
why would no country use it in their flag? the answer is really quite simple
purple was just far too expensive. No countries have purple on their flag
because up until the 1800s purple was worth more than its weight in gold
the color purple has been associated with royalty power and wealth for
centuries. In fact, Queen Elizabeth the first forbade anyone except close
members of the royal family to wear it. Purple's elite status stems from the
rarity and cost of the dye originally used to produce it the dye initially
used to make purple came from the Phoenician trading city of Tyre which is
now in modern-day Lebanon fabric traders obtained the dye from a small sea snail
that was only found in the tyre region of the Mediterranean a lot of work went
into producing the dye as more than 10,000 snails were needed to create just
one gram of tyree and purple since only wealthy rulers could afford to buy and
wear the color it became associated with the Imperial classes of Rome Egypt and
Persia purple also came to represent spirituality and holiness because the
ancient Emperor's kings and queens that wore the color were often thought of as
gods or descendants of the gods sometimes however the dye was too
expensive even for royalty third century Roman Emperor aurelion famously wouldn't
allow his wife to buy a shawl made from tyree and purple silk because it
literally cost three times its weight in gold
a single pound of dye cost three pounds of gold which is the equivalent of fifty
six thousand dollars today so since the sheer price of purple was so
astronomically high no one not
when the richest nations could afford to have purple on their flag the hue became
more accessible to lower-class is about a century and a half ago in 1856 18-year
old English chemist William Henry Perkin accidentally created a synthetic purple
compound while attempting to synthesize quinine an anti-malaria drug he noticed
that the compound could be used to dye fabrics so he patented the dye
manufactured it and got filthy rich purple dye was then mass-produced so
just about everybody could afford it the elite stopped valuing purple and the
status symbol faded away but the country flags remain the same since 1900 a
handful of new national flags have been designed and a few of them have opted to
use purple in their flag so don't be making any bets just yet hopefully you
found this interesting sometimes the simplest questions have the most
fascinating answers for more interesting videos like this one please subscribe

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The color purple did not represent which of the following:
Options: A. Holiness, B. Royalty, C. Spirituality, D. Generosity
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many countries in the world have purple on their national flag? Options: A. More than 50, B. Around 20, C. Virtually none, D. All 196 countries Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why was purple not used to represent kingdoms, civilizations, or empires throughout history? Options: A. Because it was a color of bad luck, B. Because it was too expensive, C. Because it was not a popular color, D. Because it was associated with poverty Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the original source of the dye used to produce purple? Options: A. A plant found in Europe, B. A small sea snail found in the Tyre region of the Mediterranean, C. A mineral found in Africa, D. A synthetic compound created in a lab Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did Queen Elizabeth I forbid anyone except close members of the royal family to wear purple? Options: A. Because it was a color of rebellion, B. Because it was too expensive for common people, C. Because it was associated with a rival kingdom, D. Because it was a color of mourning Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the approximate cost of a single pound of Tyrian purple dye in terms of gold? Options: A. One pound of gold, B. Two pounds of gold, C. Three pounds of gold, D. Four pounds of gold Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the discovery of synthetic purple by William Henry Perkin affect the availability of purple dye? Options: A. It made it even more expensive and exclusive, B. It had no impact on the availability of purple dye, C. It made it more accessible to lower-class people, D. It led to a ban on the use of purple dye Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was William Henry Perkin trying to synthesize when he accidentally created synthetic purple? Options: A. A new type of fabric, B. A dye for a specific type of cloth, C. Quinine, an anti-malaria drug, D. A new type of paint Correct Option: C
Question 8: How has the use of purple in national flags changed since the discovery of synthetic purple? Options: A. Many countries have added purple to their flags, B. A handful of new national flags have included purple in their design, C. The use of purple in national flags has remained the same, D. Purple has been removed from all national flags Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the social implication of the high cost of purple dye in ancient societies? Options: A. It became a symbol of poverty and oppression, B. It became a symbol of spirituality and holiness, C. It became a symbol of rebellion against the ruling class, D. It had no social implications Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about the relationship between the cost of a resource and its use in national symbols? Options: A. The cost of a resource has no impact on its use in national symbols, B. The cost of a resource determines its use in national symbols, with expensive resources being used more frequently, C. The cost of a resource can limit its use in national symbols, with expensive resources being used less frequently, D. The cost of a resource is the only factor that determines its use in national symbols Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

Although Question 9 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of question intent and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about what purple did not represent, while Question 9 asks about the social implication of the high cost of purple dye in ancient societies. However, both questions are related to the meaning and symbolism of purple.

The correct answer to the ground truth MCQ is "Generosity", which is not mentioned in Question 9. However, Question 9 does mention that purple became a symbol of spirituality and holiness, which is consistent with the ground truth MCQ's options A, B, and C.

It's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ, so Question 9 is the closest approximation.

because up until the 1800s purple was worth more than its weight in gold

centuries. In fact, Queen Elizabeth the first forbade anyone except close

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens to an organism's fur when exposed to oil?
Options: A. there is little or no effect, B. the fur of the organism usually repels the oil, C. it often becomes saturated with oil, D. organisms typically are unaffected by oil spills
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the Guimaras oil spill of 2006, and how much oil was released into the Panay Gulf? Options: A. The worst oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 1 million gallons of oil., B. The worst oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 130 thousand gallons of oil., C. A minor oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 1 thousand gallons of oil., D. A minor oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 130 million gallons of oil. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What unconventional method did locals use to contain the Guimaras oil spill, and what materials were used? Options: A. They used synthetic materials fabricated in a lab and organic stuff like human hair., B. They used only synthetic materials fabricated in a lab., C. They used only organic stuff like human hair., D. They used neither synthetic materials nor human hair. Correct Option: A
Question 3: If you were to create a hair boom to clean up a small oil spill in your community, what materials would you need? Options: A. Human hair, pantyhose, and chemical dispersants., B. Human hair and pantyhose., C. Synthetic materials and pantyhose., D. Human hair, synthetic materials, and chemical dispersants. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the difference between absorbent and adsorbent materials in the context of oil spills? Options: A. Absorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials absorb water and repel contaminants., B. Absorbent materials absorb water and blow up, while adsorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants., C. Absorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials absorb water and collect contaminants., D. Absorbent materials absorb water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials repel water and repel contaminants. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are hair booms and hair mats not the primary tools used to contain major oil spills? Options: A. They are not effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil., B. They are not widely available., C. The transcript does not explicitly state the reason, but it mentions that they were not used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon spill., D. They are too expensive to produce. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What are some of the immediate ecological impacts of oil spills? Options: A. They kill marine wildlife and destroy habitats and breeding grounds., B. They only kill marine wildlife., C. They only destroy habitats and breeding grounds., D. They have no immediate ecological impacts. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the potential benefit of using hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts? Options: A. They are made of synthetic materials and can be reused., B. They are natural, cheap, and renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Evaluate the effectiveness of hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts. What are their advantages and disadvantages? Options: A. They are effective, natural, cheap, and renewable, but not widely used., B. They are ineffective, expensive, and not renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: A
Question 9: If you were to design a new method for cleaning up oil spills, what features would you include, and how would you address the limitations of current methods? Options: A. This question requires a written response, but some possible features could include using natural and renewable materials, being effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil, and being widely available., B. Use more chemical dispersants., C. Use more synthetic materials., D. Use only hair booms and hair mats. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What role do you think hair salons and individuals can play in helping to clean up oil spills, and how can they contribute to the effort? Options: A. They can donate hair, which can be used to make hair booms and hair mats., B. They can only donate money., C. They can only volunteer their time., D. They cannot contribute to the effort at all. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 4 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the effect of oil on an organism's fur, while Question 4 asks about the difference between absorbent and adsorbent materials in the context of oil spills. Although not identical, both questions relate to the properties of materials when exposed to oil.

The correct option in the ground truth MCQ states that the fur of an organism often becomes saturated with oil, which is similar to the concept discussed in Question 4, where adsorbent materials (like hair) repel water and collect contaminants (like oil).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Phil McCrory further developed his "hair raising" theory on oil spill cleanup with the help of what equipment?
Options: A. socks, B. human hair, C. pantyhose, D. b and c only, E. all of the above are great answers
Correct Option: D

Question 7: What is the potential benefit of using hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts? Options: A. They are made of synthetic materials and can be reused., B. They are natural, cheap, and renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Evaluate the effectiveness of hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts. What are their advantages and disadvantages? Options: A. They are effective, natural, cheap, and renewable, but not widely used., B. They are ineffective, expensive, and not renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: A
Question 9: If you were to design a new method for cleaning up oil spills, what features would you include, and how would you address the limitations of current methods? Options: A. This question requires a written response, but some possible features could include using natural and renewable materials, being effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil, and being widely available., B. Use more chemical dispersants., C. Use more synthetic materials., D. Use only hair booms and hair mats. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What role do you think hair salons and individuals can play in helping to clean up oil spills, and how can they contribute to the effort? Options: A. They can donate hair, which can be used to make hair booms and hair mats., B. They can only donate money., C. They can only volunteer their time., D. They cannot contribute to the effort at all. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: "If you were to create a hair boom to clean up a small oil spill in your community, what materials would you need?"

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it asks about the materials needed to create a hair boom, which is related to Phil McCrory's "hair raising" theory on oil spill cleanup. The options also match, as the correct answer is "Human hair and pantyhose", which is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "D. b and c only" (human hair and pantyhose).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 23, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is the Guimaras oil spill of 2006 and
it's the worst of its kind in the Philippine's history. More than 130
thousand gallons of bunker oil gushed into the Panay Gulf. In an attempt to contain the spill locals turn to an unconventional method: these
freaky-looking sausage things are all filled with synthetic materials
fabricated in a lab. It's also organic stuff you can find on most continents
and probably in your shower drain. It's human hair. After the Exxon Valdez oil
spill in Alaska Phil McCroy, a hair stylist in Alabama, had a novel idea for
the cleanup effort. On TV he noticed how a sea otter's fur had become saturated with
oil and thought if that's what oil would do to an otter's fur, then the same must
be true for human hair. He took scraps of hair trimmings from
work, stuffed them into his wife's pantyhose and tested his new invention
in a small spill he created at his house. NASA's studied and confirmed Phil's
invention worked. I called every hair stylist in Alabama 'til I found him. He said that his garage was full of hair being donated from salons all over the
place, but he'd never been able to make a business out of it and so from like
about 2000, 2001 we were partners. They teamed up on the Clean Wave program. It
collects donated hair, fur, feathers, and other fibers to make recycled felted
mats and hair booms that can mop up oil spills. Turns out hair is pretty good at cleaning up oil. It repels water and can
collect contaminants. Water goes into a sponge and it blows up and that's called
absorbent but oil coats hair on the outside so like it's called adsorbent. Hair is also natural, cheap, and renewable which makes it an ideal material for
cleaning up oil spills. Making a hair boom is pretty straightforward. All you need is human hair and pantyhose. Take the hair, stuff it into the hose, and
voilà. After getting over the freaky feeling of
handling someone else's clumped up hair, place it into contaminated water and
watch the hair boom do its thing. There's little diesel spills all the
time, so like every little harbor can use that stuff. You know, it was a great way
to just kind of string from dock to dock and kind of protect your private beaches. But hair booms and hair mats haven't been the principal method to clean major
oil spills. They weren't used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater
Horizon spill, where over the course of 87 days 134 million gallons of oil
gushed into the Gulf of Mexico. Instead, crews used 1.8 million gallons of
chemical dispersants, oil skimmers, fire, and booms and barriers made of synthetic
material to clean up the mess. With oil spills, time is of the essence. The longer oil is in the ocean the harder it is to retrieve. The immediate
ecological impact of oil spills is obvious. It kills marine wildlife and
destroys habitats and breeding grounds. The chemicals used to clean up oil
spills also pose a danger to human health. As of now, hair booms and hair
mats are not the primary tools used to contain oil spills, but possibly one day
they could be. It was very interesting for us to see the public desire to help. There's so many hair salons in every city and billions more people
with hair to spare. So it's not out of the realm of possibilities that help for
the next oil spill maybe just one snip away.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the Clean Wave program collect to make their oil booms?
Options: A. feathers, B. human hair, C. pet hair, D. all of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What was the Guimaras oil spill of 2006, and how much oil was released into the Panay Gulf? Options: A. The worst oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 1 million gallons of oil., B. The worst oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 130 thousand gallons of oil., C. A minor oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 1 thousand gallons of oil., D. A minor oil spill in Philippine history, releasing over 130 million gallons of oil. Correct Option: B

Human hair and pantyhose., C. Synthetic materials and pantyhose., D. Human hair, synthetic materials, and chemical dispersants. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the difference between absorbent and adsorbent materials in the context of oil spills? Options: A. Absorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials absorb water and repel contaminants., B. Absorbent materials absorb water and blow up, while adsorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants., C. Absorbent materials repel water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials absorb water and collect contaminants., D. Absorbent materials absorb water and collect contaminants, while adsorbent materials repel water and repel contaminants. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why are hair booms and hair mats not the primary tools used to contain major oil spills? Options: A. They are not effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil., B. They are not widely available., C. The transcript does not explicitly state the reason, but it mentions that they were not used extensively in the aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon spill., D. They are too expensive to produce. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What are some of the immediate ecological impacts of oil spills? Options: A. They kill marine wildlife and destroy habitats and breeding grounds., B. They only kill marine wildlife., C. They only destroy habitats and breeding grounds., D. They have no immediate ecological impacts. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the potential benefit of using hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts? Options: A. They are made of synthetic materials and can be reused., B. They are natural, cheap, and renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Evaluate the effectiveness of hair booms and hair mats in oil spill cleanup efforts. What are their advantages and disadvantages? Options: A. They are effective, natural, cheap, and renewable, but not widely used., B. They are ineffective, expensive, and not renewable., C. They are only effective in cleaning up small oil spills., D. They are not effective in cleaning up oil spills at all. Correct Option: A
Question 9: If you were to design a new method for cleaning up oil spills, what features would you include, and how would you address the limitations of current methods? Options: A. This question requires a written response, but some possible features could include using natural and renewable materials, being effective in cleaning up large amounts of oil, and being widely available., B. Use more chemical dispersants., C. Use more synthetic materials., D. Use only hair booms and hair mats. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What role do you think hair salons and individuals can play in helping to clean up oil spills, and how can they contribute to the effort? Options: A. They can donate hair, which can be used to make hair booms and hair mats., B. They can only donate money., C. They can only volunteer their time., D. They cannot contribute to the effort at all. Correct Option: A
